a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes perimeter_triangle perimeter_hexagon :: real
assumes h0 : "perimeter_triangle = 39"
and h1 : "perimeter_hexagon = 2 * perimeter_triangle"
shows  "perimeter_hexagon = 78"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A regular hexagon is divided into six congruent equilateral triangles. If the perimeter of one of the triangles is 39 inches, what is the perimeter of the regular hexagon, in inches? The final Answer is 78
 ### Proof
 Let $s$ be the side length of the regular hexagon. The side length of the equilateral triangle is also equal to $s$.
 Solving $3s=39\text{ inches}$ gives $s=13$ inches, so the perimeter of the hexagon is $6s=6(13\text{ in. })=\boxed{78}$ inches. [asy] unitsize(10mm); defaultpen(linewidth(.7pt)+fontsize(8pt)); int i; for(i=1;i<=6;++i)
 { draw(dir(60*i)--dir(60*(i+1))); } for(i=1;i<=3;++i) { draw(dir(60*i)--dir(60*(i+3))); }[/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes perimeter_triangle perimeter_hexagon :: real
assumes h0 : "perimeter_triangle = 39"
and h1 : "perimeter_hexagon = 2 * perimeter_triangle"
shows  "perimeter_hexagon = 78"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If the perimeter of a triangle is 39, and the perimeter of a hexagon is twice the perimeter of the triangle, what is the perimeter of the hexagon? The final answer is 78.

assumes h0 : "t_hexagon = 6"
and h1 : "p_triangle = 39"

shows  "p_hexagon = 78"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A regular hexagon is divided into six congruent equilateral triangles. If the perimeter of one of the triangles is 39 inches, what is the perimeter of the regular hexagon, in inches? The final Answer is 78

 *)

fixes t_hexagon p_triangle p_hexagon :: real
assumes h0 : "t_hexagon = 6"
and h1 : "p_triangle = 39"
and h2 : "p_hexagon = t_hexagon * p_triangle"
shows  "p_hexagon = 78"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

natural problem: A regular hexagon is divided into six congruent equilateral triangles. If the perimeter of one of the triangles is 39 inches, what is the perimeter of the regular hexagon, in inches?
natural solution: Let $s$ be the side length of the regular hexagon. The side length of the equilateral triangle is also equal to $s$.

Solving $3s=39\text{ inches}$ gives $s=13$ inches, so the perimeter of the hexagon is $6s=6(13\text{ in. })=\boxed{78}$ inches. [asy] unitsize(10mm); defaultpen(linewidth(.7pt)+fontsize(8pt)); int i; for(i=1;i<=6;++i)
